title: The Custom Emoji Page has a Reflected XSS

profile.name: Slack
profile.about: All your team communication in one place, instantly searchable, and available wherever you go.

vulnerability_information:
The Custom Emoji Page has a Reflected XSS in building flash message.

The following is the PoC.
https://{team}.slack.com/customize/emoji?added=1&name=vuln"><script>alert(0);<%2Fscript>
vulnerability_information_html:
The Custom Emoji Page has a Reflected XSS in building flash message.

The following is the PoC.
https://{team}.slack.com/customize/emoji?added=1&name=vuln"><script>alert(0);<%2Fscript>

activities.message: Of course it is a cross-team exploitation because the team name of URL is easy to guess.
activities.markdown_message: Of course it is a cross-team exploitation because the team name of URL is easy to guess.

activities.message: And, of course, it could be able to steal a username and password information by creating a fake login form.
activities.markdown_message: And, of course, it could be able to steal a username and password information by creating a fake login form.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report.

When I navigate to that URL in my team, I'm not seeing the XSS execute.  Can you provide a bit more detail as to how you were able to get this URL to execute the JavaScript?  I've attached a screenshot showing my page after navigating to your link.  Where on the page are you expecting the JS to be inserted?

{F211070}

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.

activities.message:
The browser might have XSS filter or XSS auditor.
You should test reflected XSS on Firefox (without NoScript like extension) or iOS Safari, etc.

P.S. XSS filter and XSS auditor are useful but are not perfect.
There are some techniques to avoid them. see https://github.com/masatokinugawa/filterbypass/wiki/Browser's-XSS-Filter-Bypass-Cheat-Sheet

activities.message:
Oh, it might need some conditions.

I tested with voyagegroup team (My company team) first, and I got a result as the F211095 screenshot.
{F211095}

But I can't reproduce it in my personal team (as like F211070 result).

My company team has many of emojis, but my personal team does not.
activities.markdown_message:
Oh, it might need some conditions.

I tested with voyagegroup team (My company team) first, and I got a result as the __________2017-08-10_10.09.47.png (F211095) screenshot.

But I can't reproduce it in my personal team (as like Custom_Emoji_XSS.png (F211070) result).

activities.message: My company team result has an output like `Here's what it looks like :vuln">: in a sentence. `. But my personal team and F211070 just say `Your new emoji has been saved!` only. The vulnerability point might be this output.
activities.markdown_message: My company team result has an output like Here's what it looks like :vuln">: in a sentence.. But my personal team and Custom_Emoji_XSS.png (F211070) just say Your new emoji has been saved! only. The vulnerability point might be this output.

activities.message:
Thank you for your followup.

I think that message only appears if the emoji is *already saved* in the list of custom emojis.  In other words, you will only see that message if the `name` parameter in the URL is already an *existing* custom emoji name.  Is this the case here?  If so, can you explain how you were able to save this emoji?  I am not able to save an emoji named with these special characters.

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your followup.

I think that message only appears if the emoji is already saved in the list of custom emojis. In other words, you will only see that message if the name parameter in the URL is already an existing custom emoji name. Is this the case here? If so, can you explain how you were able to save this emoji? I am not able to save an emoji named with these special characters.

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.

activities.message:
Thanks for your reply.

No, I haven't saved this emoji. Of course I can't save emojis with special characters. It is reflected XSS.
Please read my guess and check our data (I didn't  mask our team name intendedly). 
I guess that Slack skips check that the specified emoji name is exsisting on Slack team which has a lot of emojis for performance reason. 

Thanks,

activities.message:
@slack, @maxfeldman
Thanks for your great work again!

a $500 bounty is for "Tier 2: Medium Severity Bugs" (XSS that affects other teammates within a team).
But this XSS is a reflected XSS, so you can attack other team without any stored data on the victim team. I think that it should be "Tier 1: High Severity Bugs" (XSS that affects more than one team (cross-team exploitation)).

Is there needed some complex conditions to fire this vulnerability?

Thanks,
Kousuke
activities.markdown_message:
@slack, @maxfeldman
Thanks for your great work again!

a $500 bounty is for "Tier 2: Medium Severity Bugs" (XSS that affects other teammates within a team).
But this XSS is a reflected XSS, so you can attack other team without any stored data on the victim team. I think that it should be "Tier 1: High Severity Bugs" (XSS that affects more than one team (cross-team exploitation)).

Is there needed some complex conditions to fire this vulnerability?

Thanks,
Kousuke

activities.message:
Hi @co3k,

We actually miscategorized this as a self-XSS (we thought it was reflected XSS but only for the original uploader of the emoji). After further inspection this could indeed have been leveraged against other teammates. However, the malicious payload needed to be stored by the attacker first, so this could only exist within a team. This is why when we tried to use your original reproduction link it did not execute for us when we tested it - that payload did not exist in our teams. However, as this was a stored XSS with a worse impact than just reflected, we're adding an additional bounty.

Thanks!
Max
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @co3k,

We actually miscategorized this as a self-XSS (we thought it was reflected XSS but only for the original uploader of the emoji). After further inspection this could indeed have been leveraged against other teammates. However, the malicious payload needed to be stored by the attacker first, so this could only exist within a team. This is why when we tried to use your original reproduction link it did not execute for us when we tested it - that payload did not exist in our teams. However, as this was a stored XSS with a worse impact than just reflected, we're adding an additional bounty.

Thanks!
Max

activities.message: Additional reward as explained above. Thanks!
activities.markdown_message: Additional reward as explained above. Thanks!

activities.message:
Hi, @maxfeldman, thanks for your reply.

> malicious payload needed to be stored by the attacker first

I've searched custom emoji page of our voyagegroup team by the following keyword.

* vuln ... not matched
* "> ... not matched
* script ...  not matched
* alert ... matched with ":alert:" emoji

So I've changed my payload to `?added=1&name=this_emoji_does_not_exist` and I've get the following result.

> Your new emoji has been saved!
> Here's what it looks like :this_emoji_does_not_exist: in a sentence. 

**Of course this emoji does not exist in our team.** IN OUR TEAM, the "Here's what it looks like ... in a sentence" message appears by any "name" parameter value (EVEN IF IT IS NOT STORED).

I think the attacker didn't need store a malicious data with some conditions. I'm sorry to trouble you, but could I ask you to do inspect or explain to solve my question?

FYI, our team has 1601 emojis.

Of course this emoji does not exist in our team. IN OUR TEAM, the "Here's what it looks like ... in a sentence" message appears by any "name" parameter value (EVEN IF IT IS NOT STORED).

I think the attacker didn't need store a malicious data with some conditions. I'm sorry to trouble you, but could I ask you to do inspect or explain to solve my question?

FYI, our team has 1601 emojis.

activities.message: @co3k no trouble at all, we're happy to dig deeper into this and reward you fairly!
activities.markdown_message: @co3k no trouble at all, we're happy to dig deeper into this and reward you fairly!

activities.message: @co3k apologies for the confusion. After digging further, you were correct. Sorry about that! This was a bit tricky to test as the behavior was different for different teams. We've rewarded you for a cross-team XSS attack.
activities.markdown_message: @co3k apologies for the confusion. After digging further, you were correct. Sorry about that! This was a bit tricky to test as the behavior was different for different teams. We've rewarded you for a cross-team XSS attack.
